title: Lecture 3
text:
Something about me…


I am an Assistant Professor of Teaching in the Department of Statistics at UBC.
My graduate teaching is focused on the Master of Data Science, specifically in statistics.
My undergraduate teaching has been mainly focused on scientific communication.
My website: https://alexrod.netlify.app
My email: alexrod@stat.ubc.ca

title: Lecture 3
text:
1. Module learning objectives
By the end of this module, you should be able to:


Identify the different types of data analysis questions and categorize a question into the correct type.
Identify a suitable analysis type to answer an inferential question, given the data set at hand.
Use the R programming language to carry out analysis to answer inferential question.
Interpret and communicate the results of the analysis from an inferential question.

title: Lecture 3
text:
2. What is the question?



The data analysis question type flow chart (Leek and Peng, 2020).

title: Lecture 3
section: 3. So you know the type of question…
text: 3. So you know the type of question…

title: Lecture 3
text:
5. The statistical landscape in R

Let us check the {tidyverse} collection of R packages designed for data science.

title: Lecture 3
section: 6. Example of an inferential analysis in R
text:
6. Example of an inferential analysis in R

Is sexual activity associated with the longevity of male fruit flies?


What kind of question is this?

Inferential!

title: Lecture 3
text:
6.1. Data

Fruit flies were divided randomly into groups of 13 each.
The response was the longevity of the fruit fly in days.
One group was kept solitary (isolated), while another was given 8 virgin females per day (high).



We will use two R libraries: {tidyverse} and {faraway} (where the data is available).


library(tidyverse)
library(faraway)

title: Lecture 3
section: 6.2. So how should we analyze this data?
text:
6.2. So how should we analyze this data?

What is our response variable? What kind of data is it?



The response is variable longevity, and it is numeric.




What is our explanatory variable? What kind of data is it?




The response is variable activity, and it is categorical.

title: Lecture 3
text:
7. Summary


Identify the kind of question.
Look at the data.
Identify a suitable statistical or machine learning method for your question and data.
Create a visualization.
Apply your statistical or machine learning method.
Maybe, create another visualization.
Interpret and communicate your assumptions and results.

title: Lecture 3
text:
Questions?






All the source files of these slides are in this public GitHub repo: https://github.com/alexrod61/MEDI504-basic-biostats-2024.

title: Lecture 3
text:
Reference

Wolberg,W.H., and Mangasarian,O.L. (1990). Multisurface method of pattern separation for medical diagnosis applied to breast cytology. In Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 87, 9193-9196.





MEDI 504A - Emerging Topics in Experimental Medicine

title: MEDI 504A - Emerging Topics in Experimental Medicine
text:
MEDI504 is a Special Topics course designed to develop literacy and conceptual understanding of data science to enable effective collaboration with data scientists as related to health research spanning the basic, clinical, population and health services.


Lecturer: G. Alexi Rodríguez-Arelis, PhD
alexrod@stat.ubc.ca
Affiliation: Assistant Professor of Teaching, Department of Statistics, UBC


By the end of this module, students should be able to:

Identify the different types of data analysis questions and categorize a question into the correct type.
Identify a suitable analysis type to answer an inferential question, given the data set at hand.
Use the R programming language to carry out analysis to answer inferential question.
Interpret and communicate the results of the analysis from an inferential question.


This website contains a Quarto presentation.
